commentBody:
Here is the Tuesday puzzle! And a fun one at that.
Thanks, and happy birthday, Adrianne.

When Dorothy's dog got into the trash, the room was in Toto disarray.

(No bones about it!)
I believe Sanrio has officially confirmed that their catlike female character is actually not a cat but a girl.

Good puzzle today, felt more like a Tuesday than Tuesday but good cluing.

I did end up looking the last name of DOROTHY and ELLE because though I knew exactly what characters I was looking for I had no idea what their last names were.

I need to remember the word EMBANC this time because I'm pretty sure I've seen the exact same clue in the last month or two.

The theme was cute and the puzzle had some nice clues.  As a birder, I tried auks for the great animals, even though they‚Äôre extinct.

Thanks to Adrienne Baik for adding circadian dysrhythmia to my lexicon.  I can‚Äôt wait to say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so circadian dysrhythmiaed‚Äù after my next time zone jumping flight.
Happy Birthday, Adrianne!  This was the fun and clever puzzle I needed after a long day. Thank you for sharing your gift with us.

Is NANCY DREW a "cover girl" because she's on book covers, or is there some other use of "cover" that I'm not thinking of?  If it's book covers, I would have preferred a different theme clue/answer pair, because "cover girl" is referring to magazine covers, and book covers are not that much different.  Other pairs like ELLE WOODS and "sister-in-law" use different meanings in the clue and the answer.  

Although I think the clue should have been "sister in law," without the hyphens.

Had to look up Elle and Dorothy, the former I had guessed but had no idea who she was, the latter's last name I was never aware of.

Good enough theme, could take or leave it.

NW was slow for me just wasn't clicking, got it eventually.

Better than yesterday's debacle.
Today‚Äôs mini features the slang phrase of the week. I won‚Äôt spoil it, but it‚Äôs there, really, truly, honestly.

Happy 21st, Adrianne üçæü•Ç
I thought this was a pretty good puzzle. Far easier than yesterday! I liked the pairing of ELLE WOODS and REESE next to each other. I also thought [Cat lady] for HELLO KITTY was clever. Let‚Äôs face it, I don‚Äôt care what Sanrio says, she looks like a cat ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüòª
POWER TIE worn with your power suit made me chuckle. I‚Äôm picturing every politician out there! üëî 
It was a year ago that the crazy fires hit two of our communities and they still haven‚Äôt recovered. This year is again off to an auspicious start. Hoping the year ahead gets much better and that our communities start the rebuilding process.

I appreciate the puzzle author agreeing with me that WOAH is a spelling that needs to stay on the internet! ;)

I felt foolish after immediately filling in MA___R_ with MARBURG. (I didn't understand why it would be a virus "of sorts" but my brain seems to be stuck on the spread of infectious diseases for some reason that I just can't imagine...)

As a zillennial, sometimes I don‚Äôt relate to many of the clues, but as I was doing this one I could tell the author was younger like me! Thanks for one of the most enjoyable puzzles I‚Äôve done yet and hope you have a great birthday :)
What a breath of fresh air after the debacle that was the Tuesday.
Happy Birthday Adrianne and congratulations on getting published.  I enjoyed solving your fun and lively creation.

Congratulations, Adrianne. Nice of you to give us all a present on your birthday.

And, fellow solvers, I'm pretty sure this is a Wednesday puzzle -- even though it's still Tuesday by the clock as I write. I'm having a tough enough time reorienting myself to weekdays as it is; don't mess with my head.

So this was definitely a ho-hum to disappointing solve for me today, for a few reasons. Agree with Derek that whether Nancy Drew is a COVERGIRL because she‚Äôs on book covers or goes undercover (which she doesn‚Äôt, really) is a stretch. I took HELLOKITTY to be a female cat, which was a pretty wide field; she certainly looks like a CAT, and if you have to go deep into San Rio lore to prove she‚Äôs a girl that also a stretch. TINKERBELL was cute. The cleverest theme entry was ELLEWOODS which was completely ruined by spoiling it with REESE‚Äîno guessing or thinking about it at all. I appreciate fitting REESE in but just clue it as ‚Äúportrayer of‚Ä¶‚Äù because Witherspoon is a gimme which just makes it too obvious. There‚Äôs also a lot of messiness given to ages; if HELLO KITTY is a human girl, she‚Äôs certainly not a LADY and categorizing DOROTHY as a QUEEN is also a stretch to make the theme work; she‚Äôs a PRINCESS at best. I‚Äôll grant some cruciverbial license here or there for an otherwise tight or remarkable theme, but this was too much for too little, in my opinion.
The rest of the fill was definitely more Monday/Tuesday-ish. I did like GENETIC makeup and EASTER as a hunting day.
Happy birthday! Great present for you and for us!
Thought this one was a fun, breezy solve
Happy birthday, Adrianne!  Fun puzzle!  I just loved all the memories these clues brought up.  Great Job!

Not one theme answer was a gimmi for me. As the crossings went in and the answers became clearer, my smile got bigger. My favorite theme set in a long time, humorous and all over the map. 

I did know Dorothy Gale from many Easter afternoon showings of The Wizard of Oz in the 50‚Äôs(?) and 60‚Äôs. I think it may be the reason we finally bought a color TV.
Woah did I go awry in the NE, until I realized the importance of being Earnest.

Much more refreshing than yesterday‚Äôs puzzle, was able to get the themed answers from the crossings rather than the clues except the top one. I also did enjoy Adrianne‚Äôs jewellery box puzzle some months ago. Fun :)

Names! Names! Names (I sound like Edina and Patsy, of ABFAB fame).  Fortunately, with help from crosses, I managed to figure them out, and for the most part, stay out of the blind alleys.  When the girls emerged, the lights went on.

Cynophilist isn't a word I use every day, so I had some trouble there, and I do eat Indian food, but I had to guess some of those.  All in all, though, the puzzle was lively and fun, and filled up quickly.  

W**H is an execrable butchery of WHOA, an imperative verb that was first recorded in the 15th century, and then somebody misspelled on the internet. As so often happens, it was accepted as being okay because nobody bothered to check it out, and it bled all over the net.  Ugh. How would you even pronounce it?

Otherwise, a terrific puzzle, Adrianne. Thank you.
ELLE WOODS gave me a chuckle.

My first time commenting but I wanted to mention how much I loved this puzzle! I loved the above-average Asia representation, from Hello Kitty and Congee to Aloo and Lee, and as a fellow college student, I felt much more comfortable with this construction compared to yesterday's. I also thought the theme and clues were quite clever, despite what others may have to say. Don't let them bring you down, great work!! Happy birthday and keep up the hard work :)
"WOAH" ??!!??Get a grip, Will, this stuff is out of control.

So everyone is going to say how easy a Wednesday puzzle that I couldn't finish was, right?

I blame the constructors for knowing things I don't know, and using them.  I blame the editors for cluing "purple boba", when I don't have any idea what "boba" is.  I suppose it's only known by the fancy-schmancy New York City people who are so cosmopolitan and who hate all us mid-westerners, and don't want us to be able to solve their puzzles.  

I think the constructor is a horrible, horrible person for knowing that Tao Terrence was a mathematician.  Or is it Terrence Tao?  It's completely unfair for such a thing to happen to me on a Wednesday.  How is anyone supposed to know that?  By reading, and learning and all that silly stuff?  That's totally bonkers.

Everybody's awful.  The constructor, the editors, the programers, the NYT legal team, the reporters, the paper boys, the editors (yeah, they're so horrible they need a second-call out).  I hope every one of them loses their jobs, and never get another chance.  That'll teach them to hurt my pride.

My self-esteem is dear to me, and it's not right for me to have to suffer the humiliation of not getting an early week puzzle.

Yeah, and to all those people yesterday who screamed about how hard the Tuesday was, I'm sorry I chided you.  You were 100% right.  If someone can't solve a puzzle, it's everyone else's fault.

üò≠   <-- This is me.  I hope you're all happy.

Delightful‚Ä¶ or would have been had I not spent as long solving it as find the two mistakes ‚Ä¶ and thanks for having someone famous in the puzzle. üòÄ

AWARD was a clever misdirection for the prize. 

Thanks to the editors and the constructor and happy birthday.

I thought Adrianne‚Äôs puzzle was strong despite some of the commentary here. At age 21! I hadn‚Äôt even completed my first Monday solve at that age. Sam, you graciously and sincerely honor Deb Amien with your wit, enthusiasm, and support for solvers of all stripes. In my mind you are her apparent.

The area with the stacked crossing of _S_ (W-9 fig.), _H_ ("___ 'nuff!"), TA_ (Mathematician Terence), CO_____EE (Savory rice porridge - that sounds disgusting btw! I can only stomach sweet porridges), and DOROTHY _ALE defeated me ü§∑üèΩ (no idea who that latter character might be). I was only able to resolve that area with lookups. Other than that the puzzle was much easier than yesterday's. I can't say I enjoyed the trivia-based theme though. Thankfully I have heard of TINKERBELL (in these puzzles) and NANCY DREW (I got the entry from crosses, not the clue; I think I learned the name from "Stranger Things," of all places), and ELLE WOODS came to me, in the end - I saw the movie once, 25 years ago.

I suppose this was just one of those foreigner-unfriendly grids ü§∑üèΩ

Oh that's where this week's Tuesday puzzle went :) No complaints here! Any puzzle featuring cat lady HELLO KITTY is fine with me <3

Also happy to see AYO again, and glad I didn't have to struggle with the spelling her last name this time lol

In all seriousness, this puzzle undid me.  

I had no idea what the cross at TAO/TARO was, having only T_O/T_RO.

I also had no idea whatsoever of the crossing at the G in DOROTHYGALE/CONGEE.  Still don't, but I figure Wordplay will tell me.

One square I can run the alphabet.  I can even do that if I'm sure of one or two possibilities for the other one.

But this time the math was just against me.  

So I keeled over.  I fell on my sword.  I gave up the ghost.  I made the trip down the River Styx.  I let the asp bite me.  I put on my blindfold, and stood against the wall.  I joined the choir invisible.  

I am an ex-puzzle solver.
Deb, being female, is a columnist emerita.
Checked it 6 times. Everything is right but won't give me my win üòû

Great fun! I very much liked the theme entries. I needed crossings for all of them, so each of them gave an Aha! and a smile.

And once I realized the greats were APES nor AukS, everything fell into place. Great auk? Really? Where did that come from?

I‚Äôm on a comment lag here but I just came here to say that I did not hate yesterday‚Äôs puzzle at all, despite the unfortunate vitriol it engendered. And I say that not only because my cousin, Sara Teasdale, was in it, though I did find that an enjoyable twist. 

I doff my cap and bow my head to all of the creators, of puzzles and poetry, who aim to enrich our shared world with their creations.
Congee is neither necessarily nor typically ‚Äúsavoury‚Äù
Thank you for a fun, breezy puzzle, Adrianne!  Happy birthday! I hope 2026 is even better for you!
Fully need someone to explain WOAH to me, was stuck on that one for ages and several times tried to think of internetisms for "woah" specifically in the process

Congratulations to the puzzle constructor; there is a lot that is good, however, I found some problems with the theme clues. Some of that could be my failure to get it. What is ‚Äúcover‚Äù about Nancy Drew? The fact that she‚Äôs a character in books? What is ‚Äúqueen‚Äú about Dorothy Gale? Simply the fact that she is female? The same with Elle Woods: is she a ‚Äúsister‚Äú because she is a woman? For me, ‚Äúsister‚Äù works a little better than ‚Äúqueen. ‚Äù

 I thought the Tinker Bell and Hello Kitty clues were terrific. A solid construction from a young creator, I thought.

I believe the last two puzzles have divided those who know what CONGEE is from those who know what LDOPA is.

For those of you smarties in the intersection of that Venn diagram...well...I guess not all of us can be smarties.  

Some of us have to be devastatingly handsome or beautiful, take your pick.
This one was so much fun. I loved the theme. Also loved the rest of the fill as well. Thank you, Adrianne for a terrific puzzle! Y‚Äôall have a fantastic day!

Felt a need to redeem myself today after yesterday‚Äôs debacle, and this one felt good. It reaffirmed that yesterday was an anomaly. Not getting discouraged, just staying the course.

Still got a little hung up in spots, but I finished without using auto-check or the wordplay column. ACK and the SHO ‚Äú‚Äônuff‚Äù clue slowed me down, but I got there in the end (32:37).

Today I learnt that ties may be powerful. Now I need to know how to recognise a POWERTIE at work or at conferences so that I may appropriately brace myself or avoid that person!

Nice puzzle Adrianne, thank you! And holy mcflashbacks, Gridlady, NANCYDREW came into my head before I could even rationalise the answer to myself. I don‚Äôt even think I read one of those books but can see the covers in my head, haha! Would she not be an ‚Äúundercover girl‚Äù? :D
Maybe Nancy Drew is a detective covering a case?
Happy 21st birthday Adrianne and congratulations on another delightful puzzle.
Now, that‚Äôs more like it. Yesterday‚Äôs was awful while this was fun and breezy. Dare I say, you could even have swapped both days over (I‚Äôd still have hated yesterday‚Äôs though üòÅ)

@Adrianne Baik

Thank you for the terrific puzzle.  I want to take it out on you that this is the first Wednesday in I don't know how long I failed to solve....but (bites fist) this is neither the time nor place.

In this forum a couple of hours ago, I posted a post that was in equal parts satirical and not-in-the-least funny.

It is total parody, and not an insult to you, or your editors.  This was  fine puzzle, even though I couldn't ....stop it...stop it now.

The whole post would be what you might call an inside joke, if it were funny.

Happy birthday! It was another tough one for me this week. I‚Äôve been a few minutes above average every day. Thank you for the excellent challenge.

I‚Äôve never heard of arepa and congee before. Yummers!

Speaking of cooking, I finished making my annual French onion soup last night. It all starts with saving every unused end of onions, garlic, shallot, and leek for the year and freezing until I have enough to make a nice base for the stock. Then I add roasted oxtails to finish the stock, simmer for a good while, and defat. Lastly, I caramelize a dozen or more of assorted onions et voila! 

I also tried my hand for only the second time at sauerkraut. My first try maybe a decade ago was a failure and I've finally gotten the resolve to try again now that I‚Äôve gotten some proper airlock fermenting Mason jar lids.

Bon apetit!
It turns out that ‚Äúseeme‚Äù has the same number as ‚ÄúAWORD‚Äù.

Happy birthday, Adrianne. May the next year bring many marvelous things.

The puzzle was fairly breezy; I finished around 25 percent under my Wednesday average. I‚Äôd never heard of CONGEE, or Terrence TAO, or AREPA, but I was able to suss them easily enough from the crossing clues.

As for the NANCY DREW ‚Äúcontroversy,‚Äù it did take me a bit to get it from the ‚ÄúCover girl‚Äù clue, but once I had enough of the letters the first thing that occurred to me was that iconic cover image to the first book in the series, The Secret of the Old Clock, which I've seen several times this past week, illustrating articles about works entering the public domain as of 1/1/2026.

Thanks for an enjoyable start to my day.
A fairly recent puzzle taught us Deb would be a wordplay column Emerita.
While doing the Mini today, I saw an oreo cookie passing by. It seemed a little down -  and its name was in all lower case.

Fun fact! The Hawaiian pizza did not originate in Hawaii, or anywhere near it, but was invented by Greek-Canadian restaurateur Sam Panopoulos at his establishment, the Satellite, in Chatham, Ontario, about 50 miles east of Windsor/Detroit. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-39072331 (That BBC article does contain one mistake: it claims "At the time, pizza was making its way into restaurants north of the border from [Detroit]." It should read "*south* of the border.")
This was a fun one. Happy Birthday, Adrianne!

Random thoughts:
‚Ä¢	The evolution of language.  In 2021, on the day WOAH was introduced to the NYT crossword, it clearly dominated the comments as a woe.  Today, not much of a mention. 
‚Ä¢	I like SHY AWAY slinking on the outer edge of the box.
‚Ä¢	Such a clever and original theme, playing on common phrases including words for females ‚Äì terrific wordplay.  
‚Ä¢	Speaking of which, PESTLE, which trips off one of moviedom‚Äôs great wordplay lines, "The pellet with the poison is in the vessel with the pestle, the chalice from the palace has the brew that is true.‚Äù  (The Court Jester, 1955.)
‚Ä¢	Love the confluence of SMOG, FOG, and DOG.
‚Ä¢	Interesting facts re the constructor: This is Adrianne‚Äôs fifth puzzle in six months, and she‚Äôs a Monday, Thursday, and Saturday away from hitting the cycle (a puzzle for every day of the week) in her first seven puzzles -- done in the Times only once before.

This was a feel-good puzzle, Adrianne, and that‚Äôs a gift.  Thank you!

Yet another word I apparently stored in my brain's junk drawer:  CONGEE.  Recalled it with the help of some crossing letters, but have no idea what it came to mind, no idea why I "know" it, and certainly never have eaten it.  Weird.
I had WTAF for 16A, and that set me back a bit in that upper right corner.  üòÖ  Only when I took it out and solved the down entries without it did it come together.  I never would have gotten WOAH.

The extremely slang term "no cap" has appeared three times in four days (Sunday's and Tuesday's main crossword, and today's mini), all clued very similarly, although today's clue didn't even mention that it is not widely accepted as common usage.

I don't object to slang, but this is a phrase I have never heard in person (despite teaching university students), and only ever in ironic/spoof contexts elsewhere. 

Do you have a gen-z mole on staff trying to get us using the term so they can laugh at us?

Thank you for a delightful puzzle, Adrianne and Happy Birthday! I hope your next trip around the ‚òÄÔ∏è is a great one and includes more puzzles from you!

I really enjoyed the theme, as well as the clever soft (egg) clue of "Day for hunting"üê∞üòâ

Happy Wednesday, everyone!

Happy Birthday! 21 is or used to be a big deal. I loved the puzzle and believe it or not the only thing that tripped me up was Elle‚Äôs last name. But I got it in the end. So much bellyaching, I see strange words as learning something new which we should all do everyday. Congee I am sure I learned through puzzles or maybe through reading and in SE Asia it was a staple at fancy hotels on the breakfast buffets so even got to try it. To those who think it sounds UNsavory, don‚Äôt yuck someone else‚Äôs yum. That‚Äôs just crass.

My iPad no longer supports the games app, so I tried the online portal instead. It‚Äôs not terrible. But the timer is way off in terms of knowing when you get a phone call or close the app.

LOVE LOVE LOVE the theme today. Not immediately obvious and greatly rewarding

Woe is me! As a confirmed DOG (& pony) LOVER, 16a really threw me for a loop. Here is why the NE was pretty thorny on this, the first Wednesday of ‚Äò26. WHOA is an assembly of concerned folks in thoroughbred racing that typically refers to the Water Hay Oats Alliance, a grassroots movement advocating for drug and medication reform.
  Nice, crisp, fresh puzzle Adrianne Baik; chock full of new entries for the NYT‚Äôs puzzles. Did some serious TINKERing to get the winning BELL to toll. And it did indeed eventually peal. Thanx all.

SEE YOU,

BRU
Does a POWERTIE require electricity?

Found this one to be a good Wednesday challenge, probably because the constructor and I seem to tune to different wavelengths.

So the theme was five female (but otherwise unrelated) characters clued in cutesy ways? Did I miss something?

In any case, I suppose that makes SHE and HERS almost thematic.

Liked the appearance of Terence TAO, but hated WOAH. Like MALWARE, I consider it a "virus of sorts". In an effort to eradicate it, I hope the editors will stop publishing puzzles in which this horrible "word" appears. ;-)
No mention yet of that famous AWARD... the Nobel?

Someone said yesterday that people only tend to talk about puzzles being too easy or too difficult.

Well this was a perfectly appropriate Wednesday, in my book. And fun theme!

I found this harder than yesterday. Apart from TINKERBELL, I wasn't very familiar with the women's names, although I got some help from crossers. GALE I hadn't heard of, nor seen Legally Blonde, and only the faintest memory of the KITTY, not being a nine year old girl, and there were the other names like JADA and TAO. 

I don't understand the upset about WHOA or WOAH, definitely a US concern! 

However, other clues were pretty clever, the make-up, hunting. Sometimes it's just what you know.

I love this grid. Crunchy enough to set the synapses going, interesting theme, not too much glue though WOAH is close to the line. Then I learn the constructor is only 21. Mind. Blown.

Finding the right female was fun. Don‚Äôt know why but I wanted Tank girl at 17A when I had the T-NK‚Äî‚Äî-L. Does that age me?

It never ceases to amaze me how young our new creators are.  Happy birthday to Adrianne and you did a great job with this puzzle!  Keep ‚Äôem coming!  You‚Äôve got years ahead of you to hone your craft.  I‚Äôm gonna definitely keep my eye out for you.  Congrats

Loved this puzzle that includes some of my favorite female characters, esp. the brilliant Elle Woods/Reese Witherspoon.

A fine way to celebrate your 21st birthday, Ms. Baik.

Wishing you a very happy one and I look forward to seeing more puzzles with your byline in the future.

I am a bit shocked that the clue for 50D got through editorial. I won't go into details so as not to spoil the answer, but it is not correct. A very easy and simple correction would have made it all better.
Great Wednesday! Great theme <3 But that NE corner... yeesh!

Also found the NE corner chewy.  Fun all around with this one.  Many thanks.  

It has been only recently that I learned DOROTHY had a last name, and a pun at that.  Credit the Wicked fanfare?

On the 16 A discussion of misspellings: our language, like us, is alive and changes. It's kinda lovely and colourful that way üòâ...

(Then again, there are also goofballs like me who just make lots of typos. Whole different thing...)

To those who have a problem with the homecoming queen clue:  Queen isn't meant literally.  It is used in order to produce the common phrase "homecoming queen" and hint that the answer refers to a female.  The question mark that ends the clue provides the license to use such a clue.

Can somebody please supply an example of the use of the word ACK in the meaning ascribed  to it in the puzzle?  I have never heard it or seen it. It is true that I may be somewhat out of date because I haven't read a comic book for many decades. .

Aha!  I have already picked out the Controversial Crossing...  My guess is 40A x 38D.  I mean, I most certainly DO try to stay abreast of all budding Mathematicians throughout the Entire World--just a little sideline we 70-Somethings like to pay attention to between rounds of Bridge and MahJong.

How did I know we'd be seeing more of Edebiri?  And that I would forget the first name?  New vocab:  "cynophilist"...which I won't be using because:  Cat Person.

The problem with Hawaiian pizza is not the HAM; it's the pineapple.  I have been making pizzas (yes, from scratch) --wait, have to do the math; where's TAO when I need him?-- since 1973, so 53 years.  (That means seldom HAM, and not as many with anchovies, alas, due to veto by DHubby/PhysDau, but otherwise every other ingredient that can legitimately be included in a decent, edible pizza.)  Number with pineapple:  NENE EGG.

Clever puzzle. Kind of a tough workout for me, but just lots of nice 'aha' moments when something finally dawned on me with some crosses. Will admit that I don't really get how the clues work with a couple of the theme answers, but that's just me. Puzzle find today. A Sunday from March 11, 2018 by Matthew Sewell with the title: "If found, call...". And that title was part of each of the theme clues. A couple of examples: 28a: "Last seen riding in a basket. If found call___(See 106 across)" DOROTHYGALE And.. 106a: "Proceed enthusiastically." GOTOTOWN (with TOTO highlighted) 86a: "Last seen chasing down clues. If found call____(see 24-across) NICKANDNORA And... 24 across: "1984" Superstate EASTASIA (with ASTA highlighted). And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/11/2018&g=28&d=A ....

This whole week so far has been a slog for me.

All three days 'well' over my averages. The good news in all of this is I've persevered and finished them without any lookups.

I can hardly wait to see what the rest of the week bestows upon us.
Wonder word woman? Adrianne Baik.
[Cat lady?] reminds me of our dear @CLM, and its answer HELLO KITTY is so close to "hello witty", which is how I feel after reading one of her posts.
I associate WOAH exclusively with Keanu Reeves. There‚Äôs even an online database with all of his cinematic WOAH‚Äôs (though they‚Äôre bowdlerized to WHOA): https://whoa.onrender.com/

Every once in a long while, I filli out a puzzle w/o the gestalt of the theme. Today was one of those times. I eagerly turned to Wordplay to see what I missed. Kind of like a cross between a brain fart & a senior moment.

A thoroughly delightful puzzle which probably should have run yesterday, but lined up with the constructor‚Äôs birthday (HBD!! ü•≥üéâ).

I have two main complaints. As others have said, some of the themed clues didn‚Äôt necessarily track with their answers. For me, that was calling Dorothy Gale a queen (maybe she does ascend the royalty in the books? But I‚Äôve never heard that). Second, the NE corner was a mess. Editors, when we need to include three answers from one tiny section into the Tricky Clues section of Wordplay, we might consider reworking something there.

Overall a much better experience than yesterday.
I must be nuts because I found this puzzle to be zippy and rather straightforward!

Really tough workout for me today. 
Especially connecting to the SW not remembering Elle Woods‚Äô name nor what a cynophilist is. Apparently my iPhone spell checker doesn‚Äôt either! 
Other difficulties today were SHO TAO TARO
For the record, I‚Äôm 63 and my current streak is well over 1500. Had me worried for bit being a Wednesday!

I found the clue for WOAH to be quite odd. I had W and A, and the only thing that I could figure out to put there was WTAF, which didn't fit at all. 

I don't think WOAH or WHOA is particularly involved in the internet
TIL, and most likely will forget, Dorothy's last name.  If I only had a brain.
I really wanted 16A to be WTAF (a far more satisfying way of expressing ‚Äúthat‚Äôs crazy‚Äù). Oh well, hope springs eternal LOL.

Finished this faster than yesterday's, at least! I struggled on that one - just didn't click on the obvs. Like the last week's Connections. Ugh. 

I beg ignorance on all things Boba and Advanced Mathematics, so yes. I did have to finish there with some WAGs. Overall thumbs up! Thanks Adrianne!

I laughed out loud, not at a clever clue, though there were many.  But my guffaw was at my own expense.  I stared at 12D for a good half minute, wondering what on earth an EAR NEST was.  Waxy buildup?  Precursor to a bird brain?

The mark of a good puzzle is even when I get it right, I get it wrong.

Thank you for highlighting women in a
Crossword puzzle!
I've once again fallen victim to the Whoa/WOAH woes.

Congratulations and HBD, Adrianne Baik! From one Capricorn to another.  :)

I love when a puzzle appreciation grows as I go through it! A clue's change of pace makes me glad ‚Äî ["Great" animals], for example. An answer makes me feel knowledgeable ‚Äî ENRON ‚Äî and another makes me feel clever. (Even though I was wrong at first pass! That would be LEFT instead of AWRY...) All the girls! From JADA at the jump to MISSY Elliot at the finale. And the yummy cross-cultural food! Who wants to [Enjoy a home-cooked meal] when your CITY offers you AREPAS, TARO boba (my favorite!), ALOO with spices freshly ground in a PESTLE, slurp-worthy CONGEE and even [Hawaiian pizza] (not my fave!). @Andrzej. I make congee, with a mix of long cooked rice, and/or millet, for my wife who has a chronic illness.   It is really easy to digest, and is kinda a comfort food for her.  I gradually have come to appreciate it‚Ä¶ a bit like oatmeal or cream of rice or cream of wheat.  The mouth feel after long cooking is kinda like soup but with less fat.  As a kid my mom would put savory stuff sometimes in cream of wheat, although we usually sweetened it.  My family growing up was utterly USA in food‚Ä¶ lots of meat loaf, pot roast, green beans, chicken.  But no fast food.

Then sometimes we now have the long stick doughnuts known as youtiao and dip them.  Like Mexican churros without the sugar and cinnamon.

Somehow my wife is less likely to eat western food than I am to eat Chinese food.  Lots of Chinese vegetables that I‚Äôve come to appreciate.  But she finds western food greasy, meaty, and often too sweet.  Her sisters are way more westernized‚Ä¶ but her palate has stayed mostly Chinese.

You‚Äôve triggered my memory of a restaurant named Warsawa in the North Berkeley gourmet ghetto near Chez Panisse, from 50 years ago.  We loved it but only could afford it a few times.  Chez Panisse was impossibly expensive and never had openings for reservations, except for a walk in pizza deal.  But you could just barely get into Warsawa with a few days advance reservation. @sonnel

It's a bit funny to read about Polish food being sold as fancy. Virtually all our staples have plebeian origins, and all the quintessentially Warsaw-ian (is that a word?) dishes are low-brow, like flaki (tripe; flaki literally means guts). Of course, these days we have luxurious restaurants with menus inspired by Polish tradition, but it's not how 99% of us eat.

Cream of wheat, always sweet, is a Polish breakfast staple, especially for kids. As a kid I enjoyed it but only when it was really thick. Some people serve it very wet and not terribly sweet - to me it becomes horrid in that version.

Cooked rice flakes are traditional food for people with stomach ache in Poland, but again,we tend to serve them rather thick, and lightly sweetened, or flavored with some fruit, like apple.

@Andrzej  I had trouble finding any record of the north Berkeley restaurant Warsawa, but I finally found some info... 1730 Shattuck, 2 blocks south of Chez Panisse.  Maybe the Warsaw proprietors still own the building.

They had the mermaid of Warsaw holding a shield with the coat of arms of Poland as their logo, sort of a wood-cut rendering.

They advertised "good food, moderately priced", and had carvings and silk artwork by Polish artists on the walls.

Yup one of my good friends growing up in Oakland had the last name of Szymkiewicz (to be his friend, you had to spell his name), originally from Krak√≥w.

All the kids knew that his father, who'd been in the Polish military, and was really, really tough, and if you ate dinner at his house, you had to eat every bite.  That was when I was like 6-12 years old.  

They had 4 sons and 1 daughter, and the kids got rebellious in the usual US way, and would insist on macaroni and cheese and hamburgers, etc.  Things not allowed at my house.  Their mom, who was incredibly sweet, could cook kids meals for them.

@sonnel It's quite hard for me to imagine Syrenka warszawska (Warsaw's Mermaid, or Little Mermaid, literally, even though she's definitely and adult) with a crest on her shield - I've been seeing her all my life all over my city, and the shield never has any art on it. Terence Tao is no mere "budding mathematician". He is perhaps one of the most brilliant mathematicians of all time. The breadth of his mastery of the field is truly staggering. Here is a quote from one of his fellow Fields medalists, lifted from Wikipedia.

British mathematician and Fields medalist Timothy Gowers remarked on Tao's breadth of knowledge:

Tao's mathematical knowledge has an extraordinary combination of breadth and depth: he can write confidently and authoritatively on topics as diverse as partial differential equations, analytic number theory, the geometry of 3-manifolds, nonstandard analysis, group theory, model theory, quantum mechanics, probability, ergodic theory, combinatorics, harmonic analysis, image processing, functional analysis, and many others. Some of these are areas to which he has made fundamental contributions. Others are areas that he appears to understand at the deep intuitive level of an expert despite officially not working in those areas. How he does all this, as well as writing papers and books at a prodigious rate, is a complete mystery. It has been said that David Hilbert was the last person to know all of mathematics, but it is not easy to find gaps in Tao's knowledge, and if you do then you may well find that the gaps have been filled a year later.

@VP

The main rule is that there really are no rules--none that can't be broken.

Some seem sacred--verb tense must agree, singular/plural must agree (though watch out for collective nouns like "crowd" or "human kind"), Fridays and Saturdays are themeless, which *seems* to imply there are never rebuses on those days.  The Sunday puzzle is bigger, though probably not harder than other days.

I've never seen a violation of the rule that the clue can't contain any part of the answer, other than common words like "the" or "an".  

A great example was from a few days ago.  One rule I'd never seen violated was having the same answer more than once in a puzzle.  But the constructor had the brilliant idea of word play on "double cross", so there were several pairs of identical answers crossing the same answer.

Short answer...if some rule is preventing you from entering what you think it right, just go for it--see if it works.  It's at most a violation of a custom, not a rule.
